root.pub-comments: "While the evidence does support a Mirndi family, the paucity of lexical and grammatical cognates suggests that the break-up of the family is of some considerable time depth" (Harvey 2008: 125). "I have proposed that the Mirndi languages can be divided into three subgroups: Jingulu, Ngurlun, ... [and] Yirram" (Harvey 2008: 125).
root.publications: Multiple sources Integrated by The LINGUIST List. , Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.), Dousset, Laurent. AusAnthrop: Research and resources on Aboriginal Australia. http://www.ausanthrop.net/index.php. (19 October, 2009.), 2011. AUSTLANG: Australian Indigenous Languages Database. http://austlang.aiatsis.gov.au/main.php. (19 October, 2009.), Tindale, Norman B. 1974. Aboriginal tribes of Australia, their terrain, environmental controls, distribution, limits, and proper names. With four sheet map. Berkeley & Canberra: University of California Press. , Chadwick, Neil. 1997. The Barkly and Jaminjungan Languages: a Non-Contiguous Genetic Grouping in North Australia. In Darrell T Tryon & Michael Walsh (eds.), Boundary Rider: Essays in Honour of Geoffrey O'Grady, 95-106. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics. , Harvey, Mark. 2008. Proto Mirndi: A Discontinuous Language Family in Northern Australia. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 9780858835887, Green, Ian & Rachel Nordlinger. 2004. Revisiting Proto-Mirndi. In Claire Bowern & Harold Koch (eds.), Australian Languages: The classification and comparative method, vol. 249, 291-311. Amsterdam: John Benjamins.

child.pub-comments: "…the Ngurlun languages share very particular pronominal, gender and tense/aspect/mood features; a range of these features have no correspondences in the other Mirndi languages and are thus better considered as innovations of a (low-level) sub-group than as retentions from proto-Mirndi. No such considerations apply, however, to a comparison of Jingulu and Ngurlun; on the basis of the current data there are no sets of formal features which stand out as shared innovations of Jingulu and Ngurlun and which would compel us to set up a Barkly node" (Green and Nordlinger 2004: 309).
child.publications: Multiple sources Integrated by The LINGUIST List. , Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.), Dousset, Laurent. AusAnthrop: Research and resources on Aboriginal Australia. http://www.ausanthrop.net/index.php. (19 October, 2009.), 2011. Berkeley & Canberra: University of California Press. , Harvey, Mark. 2008. Proto Mirndi: A Discontinuous Language Family in Northern Australia. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 9780858835887, Green, Ian & Rachel Nordlinger. 2004. Revisiting Proto-Mirndi. In Claire Bowern & Harold Koch (eds.), Australian Languages: The classification and comparative method, vol. 249, 291-311. Amsterdam: John Benjamins.

child.pub-comments: "The languages of the Yirram group occupy areas around the lower Victoria River in the Northern Territory near the border with Western Australia" (Chadwick 1997: 95).
child.publications: Multiple sources Integrated by The LINGUIST List. , Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. child.pub-comments: "Whatever the synchronic relation of Jaminjungan and Nungali, we will see that they derive from a common protolanguage which has no other daughter languages. Following Chadwick (1978), the language family consisting of Jaminjungan and Nungali is referred to as Yirram" (Harvey 2008: 3).
child.publications: Multiple sources Integrated by The LINGUIST List. , Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. In Claire Bowern & Harold Koch (eds.), Australian Languages: The classification and comparative method, vol. 249, 291-311. Amsterdam: John Benjamins.

child.pub-comments: "Whatever the synchronic relation of Jaminjungan and Nungali, we will see that they derive from a common protolanguage which has no other daughter languages. Following Chadwick (1978), the language family consisting of Jaminjungan and Nungali is referred to as Yirram" (Harvey 2008: 3). "In the west are Nungali, and the closely related dialects Jaminjung and Ngaliwurru, making up a language we refer to as 'Jaminjungan'" (Green and Nordlinger 2004: 292).

child.pub-comments: "Wambayan shares a number of innovations with Ngarnka, and together they constitute the Ngurlun subgroup" (Harvey 2008: 3). "…the Ngurlun languages share very particular pronominal, gender and tense/aspect/mood features; a range of these features have no correspondences in the other Mirndi languages and are thus better considered as innovations of a (low-level) sub-group than as retentions from proto-Mirndi. No such considerations apply, however, to a comparison of Jingulu and Ngurlun; on the basis of the current data there are no sets of formal features which stand out as shared innovations of Jingulu and Ngurlun and which would compel us to set up a Barkly node" (Green and Nordlinger 2004: 309).
